Invocation

Motion to spread the Invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Powers.

Council Member Powers moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Resolution calling upon the New York City Department of Education to expand career-connected learning programs and opportunities at all public high schools.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Education
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Department of Education to expand career-connected learning programs and opportunities at all public high schools.

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Immigration
Items.AgendaNote: REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON IMMIGRATION

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, A.568/S.1802 prohibiting municipalities from requiring all employers to check prospective employees’ work authorization status by using the federal electronic verification system and prohibiting employers from checking the employment authorization status of an existing employee or an applicant who has not been offered employment.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Immigration
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 7 Council Members formally noted their intent to vote negative against this item: 
Council Members Carr, Holden, Kagan, Paladino, Vernikov, Yeger, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting municipalities from requiring all employers to check prospective employees’ work authorization status by using the federal electronic verification system. (A.568/S.1802)

Items.MatterName: Feasibility study on housing adaptation and mobility, voluntary residential buyouts, and related support services for residents of high-risk flood zones.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: Civil service examination fee waivers.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MatterName: Recognizing April 13 annually as Borinqueneers Day in the City of New York.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Technology
Items.MatterName: Establishing an office of algorithmic data integrity.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to requiring the department of small business services to conduct a study on the economic impact of film and television production on local businesses and develop a plan to mitigate lost revenue attributable to filming
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Small Business
Items.MatterName: Requiring the dept of small business services to conduct a study on the economic impact of film and television production on local businesses and develop a plan to mitigate lost revenue attributable to filming.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the 311 customer service center to indicate that an agency is unable to respond to a service request or complaint and implement protocols providing proof of action
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Technology
Items.MatterName: Requiring the 311 customer service center to indicate that an agency is unable to respond to a service request or complaint and implement protocols providing proof of action.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Collecting information on the accessibility of private buildings and publishing this information online.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
Items.MatterName: Establishment of a parking enforcement unit within the department of transportation.

Items.MatterName: Community News and Small Business Support Act. (H.R. 4756)

Items.MatterName: Increase Medicaid reimbursement to cover eight pre- and post-natal visits, as well as delivery support by doulas.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of health and mental hygiene to develop educational materials regarding marijuana, for distribution to youth services programs and students.

Items.MatterName: Environmental conservation law, in relation to extended producer responsibility for rechargeable batteries. (S.643-C /A.7339-A)

Items.MatterName: Create unlimited transfers within the two-hour period of paying the Metropolitan Transportation Authority subway or bus fare for pay-per-ride users.

Items.MatterName: Flood evacuation plans for tenants.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting smoking on sidewalks immediately adjoining parks, imposing civil penalties for violating such prohibition, and increasing civil penalties for smoking in parks.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the licensing of tire shops
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer and Worker Protection
Items.MatterName: Licensing of tire shops.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to offering community service in lieu of civil penalties for certain littering violations
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Offering community service in lieu of civil penalties for certain littering violations.

Items.Title: Resolution designating October as Youth Empowerment Month annually in the City of New York to recognize, appreciate, and celebrate the successes of young people and their contributions to school and community life.

Items.MatterName: October as Youth Empowerment Month annually in the City of New York.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, S.1037/A.423 to require public schools to obtain prior written consent from parents or eligible students before releasing their personal information to third party contractors.

Items.MatterName: Require public schools to obtain prior written consent from parents or eligible students before releasing their personal information to third party contractors. (S.1037/A.423)

Items.MinutesNote: At this point the Speaker (Council Member Adams) made the following announcements:

Whereupon on motion of the Speaker (Council Member Adams), the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) adjourned these proceedings to meet again for the Stated Meeting of Tuesday, November 2, 2023.

MICHAEL M. McSWEENEY, City Clerk
Clerk of the Council
The Majority Leader (Council Member Powers) presiding as the President Pro Tempore.

The presence of a quorum was announced by the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers).

There were 48 Council Members marked present at this Stated Meeting.

Items.Title: Passed The Consent Agenda
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that these files be approved by consent vote.

Items.MinutesNote: The Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

The following files were removed from the General Order Calendar and voted separately:

Int. No. 790-B,  VOTE: 39-6-0
Negative: CMs Carr, Holden, Kagan, Paladino, Vernikov, and Yeger;
Present, Not Voting: CMs Barron, Richardson Jordan, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

Int. No. 1164-A,  VOTE: 39-6-0
Negative: CMs Carr, Holden, Kagan, Paladino, Vernikov, and Yeger.
Present, Not Voting: CMs Barron, Richardson Jordan, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

Res. No. 807,  VOTE: 44-1-0
Negative: CM Yeger.
Present, Not Voting: CMs Barron, Richardson Jordan, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

Res. No. 808,  VOTE: 44-1-0
Negative: CM Yeger.
Present, Not Voting: CMs Barron, Richardson Jordan, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

See files for individual votes.

Council Member Barron's motion to be allowed to vote after the announcement of the General Orders vote totals drew an objection from Council Member Williams.  Since he did not have the unanimous consent of the Council Members present, Council Member Barron was not allowed to cast his vote on items coupled on the General Orders Calendar.
